p: Following cell surface tethering, Vpu-defective HIV-1 viral particles are subject to internalization into endosomal compartments, probably resulting in degradation, and dominant-negative mutants of Rab5a can inhibit this process [ 2, 42]. Interestingly, one study identified BCA2/rabring 7, a putative endocytic E3 ubiquitin ligase, as a tetherin-interaction factor capable of enhancing the internalization and degradation of tethered HIV-1 virions from the cell surface [ 43]. An unresolved question is whether the linkage of tetherin with the actin cytoskeleton helps to recruit tetherin to sites of virus budding or plays a role in re-internalization of tethered virions [ 17, 25].
